Award.AwardTitle: College of Lake County NSF Engineering, Computer Science, and Technology Scholars Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The College of Lake County NSF Scholars Program is awarding up to 30 scholarships each year to full-time Engineering Transfer, Computer Science, and Electrical Engineering Technology students who have demonstrated both academic potential and financial need. Special emphasis is being given to recruitment from underrepresented groups in these academic areas - including women, minority students, and the disabled. Scholars are being organized into cohorts, which are subsequently supported by activities such as individualized advisement, structured tutorials, mentoring, and a summer orientation.

The College of Lake County (CLC) S-STEM scholar program provides a model for increasing the recruitment and retention rate of students underrepresented in these STEM disciplines. Once fully established and evaluated, many of the mentoring and student support strategies used in this project can be implemented and continued with nominal cost to an institution. With institutions like CLC accounting for almost half of the nation's STEM undergraduates and over half of all minorities in higher education, the project offers the opportunity for broad impact on the STEM pipeline.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The College of Lake County (CLC) NSF Engineering, Computer Science, and Technology Scholars Program awarded scholarships to 92 Engineering and Computer Science students over a 5 year period ending in July 2018. The scholarships helped ease the financial burden of attending college, which, in addition to advising assistance, internship placement, tutoring, and mentoring, boosted the success rate of the NSF scholars above the rest of the CLC Engineering student population. NSF scholars had a 18% higher success rate, a 13% higher transfer rate, and a 16% higher graduation rate than the comparison group at CLC. The NSF scholars all had demonstrated financial need according to Federal Financial Aid criteria.   The NSF group consists of a larger percentage of underrepresented students (ethnic minority and/or female) than the Comparison Group (60.0% and 36.6%, respectively).  During the grant period, the percentage of ethnically underrepresented students in the engineering program increased 7%, the percentage of women engineering students increased 2.1%, and the percentage of students with demonstrated financial need dropped 4%. Other, less direct outcomes that resulted from the grant program included the development of a new “Intro to Engineering class”, growth of CLC’s engineering internship program, and a new makerspace/fablab – “The Baxter Innovation Lab”.  These developments have been influenced by the students in the NSF Scholars program and the program activities, and are expected to have a positive influence on engineering students and the broader Lake County community in terms of STEM outreach for years to come.


Last Modified: 11/19/2018
Modified by: Robert Twardock

Other, less direct outcomes that resulted from the grant program included the development of a new "Intro to Engineering class", growth of CLC?s engineering internship program, and a new makerspace/fablab – "The Baxter Innovation Lab". These developments have been influenced by the students in the NSF Scholars program and the program activities, and are expected to have a positive influence on engineering students and the broader Lake County community in terms of STEM outreach for years to come.
